importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of the Hamas attacks that led to the abduction of hostages and the beginning of the hostage crisis.
Date on which Arye Zalmanovich is believed to have been killed in captivity by Hamas.
Date when the US-proposed ceasefire agreement was signed, requiring Hamas to return hostages within 72 hours.
Date when the bodies of Arye Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar were returned to Israel from Gaza.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the ceasefire agreement was being implemented, including the return of deceased hostages and the ongoing efforts to recover missing bodies.

keyTakeAways: The body of Arye Zalmanovich, the oldest hostage taken by Hamas during the October 7 attacks, was returned to Israel on October 22, 2025.
Tamir Adar, a 38-year-old farmer and educator from Kibbutz Nir Oz, died defending his community during the attacks and his body was also returned.
Hamas has returned 15 of the 28 deceased hostages under the US-proposed ceasefire agreement, but not all bodies have been recovered or identified.
Hamas claims significant effort and special equipment are needed to locate and recover remaining bodies in Gaza, with one body previously misidentified.
The U.S. Vice President JD Vance visited Israel and emphasized the difficulty of recovering all bodies, stating that it is not going to happen overnight.
The return of the bodies is critical for families to conduct proper burials and for psychological closure.

namedEntities.name: Arye Zalmanovich
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 85-year-old Israeli citizen and founding member of Kibbutz Nir Oz, abducted by Hamas on October 7, 2023, believed killed in captivity on November 17, 2023. He was the oldest hostage taken by Hamas.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Arye Zalmanovich is relevant to the world outside the article because he represents the human cost of the Hamas attacks and the immense emotional and societal toll on families of hostages, especially as one of the oldest and most symbolic victims of the conflict.

namedEntities.name: Tamir Adar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 38-year-old Israeli farmer and educator from Kibbutz Nir Oz who died defending his community on October 7, 2023, and whose body was later returned to Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tamir Adar is relevant to the world outside the article because his story illustrates the personal sacrifices made by ordinary citizens during the conflict, highlighting themes of bravery, family, and community.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian militant group responsible for the October 7, 2023 attacks on Israel, which led to the abduction and killing of numerous hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is relevant to the article because it is the group responsible for the hostage-taking and the return of bodies, directly impacting the humanitarian and political dimensions of the conflict.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The military force of Israel, which reported on the recovery and identification of hostage bodies and the initial response to the attacks.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF is relevant to the article because it played a central role in identifying, reporting on, and managing the return of hostages and their bodies, particularly in the context of military operations and humanitarian coordination.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister who expressed sorrow over the loss of Zalmanovich and Adar and acknowledged the emotional impact on their families.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Netanyahu is relevant to the article because as head of government, his public statements reflect the national response to the loss of hostages and the political implications of the ceasefire and recovery efforts.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The country that proposed and supported the ceasefire agreement signed on October 9, 2025, requiring Hamas to return hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The U.S. is relevant to the article because its diplomatic initiative and ceasefire proposal directly shape the conditions under which hostages are to be returned and the broader international response to the conflict.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Vice President who visited Israel and addressed concerns about the recovery of bodies and the fragile ceasefire.

namedEntities.name: Kibbutz Nir Oz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A community in southern Israel where both Arye Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar lived, founded by Zalmanovich, and a site of the initial attacks.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kibbutz Nir Oz is relevant to the article because it was the location of the attacks and the homes of both hostages, symbolizing the direct impact of violence on civilian communities.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli institution that received the coffins for formal identification and investigation of the causes of death.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The institution is relevant because it provided the scientific and legal process for identifying the victims and determining the causes of death, crucial for closure and accountability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The body of Arye Zalmanovich, the oldest hostage taken by Hamas during the October 7, 2023 attacks, was returned to Israel on October 22, 2025, along with that of Tamir Adar, a farmer and educator who died defending his community. Both men were from Kibbutz Nir Oz and had strong ties to agriculture and community. Their return is part of Hamas's compliance with the U.S.-proposed ceasefire agreement, which requires the return of all deceased hostages within 72 hours. However, Hamas has not returned all bodies, and some remain missing or buried under rubble. The Israeli government, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, expressed deep sorrow, while U.S. Vice President JD Vance emphasized the difficulty and long-term nature of recovery, stating that it will not happen overnight. This development reflects broader challenges in recovering human remains and the ongoing political and humanitarian implications of the conflict.
title: Oldest hostage taken by Hamas among two deceased returned to Israel Tuesday
